text: Your intelligence probably won't decrease but your aptitude at the skills you were employing before AI assistance will probably worsen. This is actually a studied phenomenon in aviation, the degradation of fundamental flight skills as the role of a Pilot slowly morphs into one of Automation Monitor. It was one of the (many, many) factors which contributed to the Air France 447 disaster in 2009.

It's great for writing performance evaluations and wording criticism constructively, HR loves it, my employees definitely love it, my performance evals are actually meaningful and motivational and I don't have to spend days wordsmithing and individualizing them for all of my direct reports, I can type a freeform narrative of their strengths and challenges and it spits out a perfect eval. Gemini and Chatgpt work just as well for this IMO. 

It's also great for sentiment analysis in emails, something I personally struggle with so it's like an aide. It's a great sounding board to run my emails through to make sure the tone is appropriate and constructive, something I've also struggled with in the past. 

The thing is, using it makes me BETTER at the things I struggle with because I see the difference between where I'm at and the ideal goal laid out explicitly. It's made me a better communicator with my staff and with patients.

"I can't shake the feeling that if I start using AI, my intelligence might start to decrease."

As long as I still see posts that use LLM like Google and laugh at it making mistake, I won't consider AI as IQ harvester. I bet before we have AGI, only smart AI users can bring good AI answers.

Agree on all points - your editing and critical thinking skills have to go up. The feeling reminds me of the early Web, especially early Wikipedia - you were grateful to have it, but always evaluating what you were reading.
Excel didn't kill my math skills. I do more math than ever.

Your instincts are correct about this.

>MIT study mentioned found that ChatGPT mostly serves as a substitute for human effort, not a complement to our skills. In fact, the vast majority of participants didn‚Äôt even bother editing the AI‚Äôs output. This is a problem I see repeatedly when people first use AI: they just paste in the exact question they are asked and let the AI answer it.

Mollick, Ethan. Co-Intelligence: Living and Working with AI (p. 120). Penguin Publishing Group. Kindle Edition. 

Here is the study:  
[https://economics.mit.edu/sites/default/files/inline-files/Noy\_Zhang\_1.pdf](https://economics.mit.edu/sites/default/files/inline-files/Noy_Zhang_1.pdf)

Using AI at work?
I am tempted to use AI in certain aspects of my position, however, I have some reservations. I can't shake the feeling that if I start using AI, my intelligence might start to decrease. Where is the line drawn between increasing productivity versus plain laziness? It's honestly reminiscent of the spelling and grammar and calculator debates people have, where they say those tools are making people dumber. 

On the other hand, I see these companies starting to use AI without taking any of that into consideration because they value increasing productivty more than anything else. So part of me wants to just say, "f it."

I agree. The voice recorder transcriber and summarizer on my phone has been a game changer. I see even zoom is getting in on this AI stuff. Although even with this very useful feature, I try and make sure to still jot down some personal notes and ofc actively listen to the things that are being said.
Socrates was right. I felt a lot smarter before I started reading and realize how many words I don‚Äôt understand.

I kind of agree, and I use it every day. English is not my mother tongue and I have lost all confidence in sending long emais if I don't grammar/language check them with AI first. I feel my clients will think I had seizure üòÖ

I have been in corporate America for decades and can‚Äôt remember a time when intelligence has been prioritized. Efficiency is. You‚Äôre going to get lapped if you don‚Äôt start using the tools that everyone else is to make you more efficient. 
Just do it. (Within the parameters of what your company allows. Don‚Äôt put information into any tool that shouldn‚Äôt be outside your org unless the company has approved the tool for use. Security issues are real. If you‚Äôre not sure, ask IT and/or legal.)

## Welcome to the r/ArtificialIntelligence gateway
### Question Discussion Guidelines

---

Please use the following guidelines in current and future posts:

* Post must be greater than 100 characters - the more detail, the better.
* Your question might already have been answered. Use the search feature if no one is engaging in your post.
    * AI is going to take our jobs - its been asked a lot!
* Discussion regarding positives and negatives about AI are allowed and encouraged. Just be respectful.
* Please provide links to back up your arguments.
* No stupid questions, unless its about AI being the beast who brings the end-times. It's not.

###### Thanks - please let mods know if you have any questions / comments / etc

*I am a bot, and this action was performed automatically. Please [contact the moderators of this subreddit](/message/compose/?to=/r/ArtificialInteligence) if you have any questions or concerns.*
AI is not an easy button to do your job for you. It's a tool to help you do your job better. You still need to know what you're doing, know how to use it, and most importantly, know when it's wrong.

Yep. My team tracks how AI saves us actual time. Like we tested Copilot for Excel and saw a 50% drop in formula troubleshooting time. Not huge individually‚Äîbut across a week? Adds up. This [Hubstaff study](https://hubstaff.com/ai-productivity-shift?utm_source=reddit&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=ai-report-organic-ai-threads) I read said only 4% of work time is AI-assisted right now, but the gains are real when you go beyond ChatGPT.
If you are not going to start using AI, you‚Äôll lose your job.
If you don't become adept at using AI for your job, your employability will be trending to zero.

For my particular use cases, I take a lot of notes to help me keep track of projects and when I am asked to write up reports of the latest status, I use AI such as ChatGPT, CoPilot or even DeepSeek now to help me take all of my notes and organize them into bullet points and section titles. Huge time saver plus the reports I generated look super professional and informative. 

We are moving from an era of ‚Äúwhat you know‚Äù to an era of ‚Äúcan you find the information‚Äù. We live in a time where we are expected to process vast amounts of information, ranging from your professional work down to political stuff. The human brain is not made to process this level of information and we need to shift our thinking on how we process it or even store it. AI can be a huge time saver for troubleshooting and help you consider different approaches to a particular problem. Some might call this laziness but I think of it more as efficiency but it allows my brain to focus on other important tasks vs going through the weeds of the details and helps keep me overall more sane
This is what we thought about in the Eighties when digital calculators came out. Forgot how to do simple arithmetic.
lol.. you'll be fine

Your reflection is both valid and important. The line between leveraging tools and over-relying on them is nuanced. AI, like calculators or spell-check, is most powerful when used as a partner‚Äînot a replacement‚Äîfor human intelligence. For instance, automating repetitive tasks can free up mental space for creativity, strategy, and deeper problem-solving, which are inherently human strengths.

The key lies in intentionality. Ask: Does this tool amplify my skills, or am I outsourcing my growth? For example, using AI to draft emails might save time, but refining the output ensures you stay sharp. Similarly, leaning on AI for data analysis could let you focus on interpreting results and making decisions.

Companies prioritizing productivity aren‚Äôt wrong, but sustainable success requires balancing efficiency with skill retention. Propose guidelines for ethical AI use in your role‚Äîlike auditing outputs or dedicating time to ‚Äúunplugged‚Äù critical thinking. This way, you harness AI‚Äôs benefits without compromising your development.

Ultimately, tools shape us only if we let them. Staying curious and deliberate ensures AI elevates, not erodes, your capabilities.

I'm wary of AI because I've seen how it increasingly just gets everything wrong when it comes to translating basic contextual information from plain English into more plain English, often excising important data points or reinterpreting semantically similar ideas "like height" and "size" into confusing concepts.

AI is basically a very fast-thinking 2-year-old.

So, excel is a perfect example of a good use case. Excel is a series of single-form one-to-one calculations that can be strung together into larger and more complex formulae. But you can SEE the calculations in the spreadsheet. There's no black box, excel isn't inventing new ideas to explain what you're doing.

AI is safe if it's taking a thing you said and moving it to another place. Or it's taking numbers and symbols that don't have any other obvious semantic understanding and translating them into plain language like a funnel or one-way door.

Basically, if there's ambiguity in a translation from one place to another and you don't know the right way to translate it, you're going to get screwed relying on AI systems right now and ignoring the original sources. If the ambiguity is YOUR OWN INFORMATION or YOUR OWN DATA then you're a lot safer wielding AI as a stopgap or shortcut.

NOTE: The director of The Brutalist used this as a good case. A native speaker, he used AI to get the accents right for his actors. This was only possible because HE was already a native speaker and could edit, rerun, adjust, and tweak the final results. If he didn't speak it, it could easily be just gibberish.

I kind of agree, and I use it every day. English is not my mother tongue and I have lost all confidence in sending long emais if I don't grammar/language check them with AI first. I feel my clients will think I had seizure üòÖ

I use it less than I probably could. The main reason is corporate information and proprietary code. Unless you have a completely closed system that is secure that only corporate employees can use. whatever you put in there is then sucked up into the wild and "learned". It is a real security risk that people don't seem to be aware of. Especially code.

Why would I pay 2 people the same if one can do it faster?
Moreover, why would I pay more by hiring a good professional for a thing that can be done more or less the same by a mediocre professional. 

If you are not using AI, you ar wasting yourself time and your employer money, it‚Äôs that simple. 

Of course, we are presuming that data remains confidential and people know how to use it without training models on confidential data.

It's great for writing performance evaluations and wording criticism constructively, HR loves it, my employees definitely love it, my performance evals are actually meaningful and motivational and I don't have to spend days wordsmithing and individualizing them for all of my direct reports, I can type a freeform narrative of their strengths and challenges and it spits out a perfect eval. Gemini and Chatgpt work just as well for this IMO. 

It's also great for sentiment analysis in emails, something I personally struggle with so it's like an aide. It's a great sounding board to run my emails through to make sure the tone is appropriate and constructive, something I've also struggled with in the past. 

The thing is, using it makes me BETTER at the things I struggle with because I see the difference between where I'm at and the ideal goal laid out explicitly. It's made me a better communicator with my staff and with patients.

I use it frequently and I do not feel like its having a negative effect. Instead of spending 30 minutes refactoring a my code because I need to slightly change its inputs I just have an AI do that so I can focus on the interesting stuff. Basically yes it does my work for me but that just lets me do even more work.

I use it a lot and in fact my job had a whole training on how to use it and implores us to use it to increase productivity. I do not feel like it‚Äôs making me dumber at all. It just reduces headaches.¬†

Socrates thought books would make us stupid.

Since then people have worried the same thing about almost every new technology, be it phones, texting, the internet, wikis and search engines, social media, etc.

Personally I feel AI is an amazing way to learn new things. You can just keep asking it to explain it so it's easier to understand, and it does.

Agree on all points - your editing and critical thinking skills have to go up. The feeling reminds me of the early Web, especially early Wikipedia - you were grateful to have it, but always evaluating what you were reading.

I‚Äôd take into consideration that all data you enter will be uploaded and become part of the training data. Depending how sensitive the data is for your employer, that may have implications.

I am very rusty at long division. Have not done it in 50 years. I have had a successful engineering career anyway.  I also prefer an electric sander. I drive a car rather than walking.  There is no problem using tools. If a tool is lost you can relearn to do the job manually.

Plain laziness is the fundamental aspect of an ¬†increasing productivity, there is no point to do it with out.
Depending on how often you find yourself flying a plane in the average work week, you should be alright.

If you are

- getting an AI to teach you stuff
- using an AI to do gruntwork, which you then review and refine as you would the work of any smart-but-inexperienced intern
- developing your skills at using the new tools

... then I think you're probably fine. None of that is inimical to your own self-improvement.

The important thing is to remember to keep your brain engaged and yourself in the driving seat.

(source: I've been using AI tools to improve my productivity at writing code for the last six months. I quickly realised that, if anything, you need to be _more_ present and engaged, similar to the difference between walking and driving)

Ai hasn't dumbed me down but it does make me feel like I'm expected to accomplish more, for less.
I use it at work but don't put anything confidential in , take loads of random notes in the field and get it to organise it for me in a structured manor . Superb

Steer into the skid. AI is here, and it‚Äôs going to change everything.
